newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo naphtha up, LSWR seen done over $17.50/bbl.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo naphtha up, LSWR seen done over $17.50/bbl.

text.p: Tokyo naphtha prices were higher on Thursday in tandem with overnight crude, while 100,000 barrels of South Korean low sulphur waxy residue (LSWR) were traded at slightly over $17.50 per barrel, traders said.

They also said the naphtha market remained unaffected by an oil spill from the supertanker Diamond Grace, which on Wednesday hit a reef in shallow waters in Tokyo Bay and leaked an estimated 1,550 kl of crude oil.
The spot LSWR cargo for first-half July loading was said to have been sold to a Japanese oil firm.
Open-spec naphtha was assessed at $201.75/203.00 per tonne for first-half September delivery, up from Wednesday's $200.75/201.25.
In spreads, first-half August/first-half September changed hands at even. It was quoted at about minus 75 to minus 50 cents earlier this week.
However, some traders said the deal did not reflect the general trend, adding that the contango in near-term naphtha spreads was expected to widen, rather than contract.
"Prompt cargoes are likely to remain on the weak side with good availability for second-half August," one trader said.
